docs.lead_paragraph: The White House on Sunday pushed out the chairman of General Motors and instructed Chrysler to form a partnership with the Italian automaker Fiat within 30 days as conditions for receiving another much-needed round of government aid.

headline.main: Washington Raises the Pressure on Detroit

docs.abstract: The White House on Sunday pushed out the chairman of General Motors and instructed Chrysler to form a partnership with the Italian automaker Fiat within 30 days as conditions for receiving another much-needed round of government aid. docs.lead_paragraph: Will the Treasury Department's latest plan to save the American banking system work?

headline.main: This Time, Geithner's Plan for Banks Makes Sense

docs.abstract: Will the Treasury Department's latest plan to save the American banking system work? To The New York Times's Joe Nocera, it just might. docs.lead_paragraph: Nearly seven years after National Century Financial Enterprises collapsed in a $2.9 billion fraud, its founder, Lance K. Poulsen, was sentenced to 30 years in prison on Friday in one of the harshest white-collar punishments in history, The New York Times's Zachery Kouwe reported.

headline.main: National Century Executive Gets 30 Years for Fraud

docs.abstract: Nearly seven years after National Century Financial Enterprises collapsed in a $2.9 billion fraud, its founder, Lance K. Poulsen, was sentenced to 30 years in prison on Friday in one of the harshest white-collar punishments in history, The New York Times's Zachery Kouwe reported. Mr. Poulsen was convicted in October of leading a vast fraud [...]

docs.lead_paragraph: While many European companies have long turned to shorter workweeks and mandatory time off in economic downturns, the idea has never really caught on in the United States. Despite reports of unpaid furloughs and wage cuts, American companies continue to rely heavily on layoffs to control labor costs.

headline.main: Europe's Solution: Take More Time Off

docs.abstract: European companies have long turned to shorter workweeks during times of economic downturn. Can the idea take hold in the U.S?
docs.snippet: European companies have long turned to shorter workweeks during times of economic downturn. Can the idea take hold in the U.S?
